I realize I’m kind of late to the vid but I was wondering something. So I was born with red hair (my mom had black and my dad red) but when I got chemotherapy to treat a cancer I got a few years ago, I turned into a blond. Just curious since you said it was something that occurs when you have the allele for red hair (which I don’t have now that I’m blonde?)

Thank you! I love learning, but especially when it’s something that directly applies to me. I don’t know how or why but I definitely have that albino Irish skin (literally never tans; just turns red then mutates into cancer), and always had that decreased sensitivity exactly like you described. Doctors checked me for a pain disorder but determined I’m just “on the far end of the tactile sensation spectrum,” because I can feel pain it’s just significantly reduced. 

Oddness —>

The reason it’s a bit odd in my case is because I’m of aboriginal American and African descent; although tons of European mixed in there as well like most Americans (of all skin tones). I don’t have red hair though, so I’d guess the 2 aren’t dependent. On the other hand I have (naturally) multicolored hair (and skin, and eyes), so maybe it’s some unique mutation I have or something. 

Details —>

My facial/body hair grows in in a range of blonde to red or auburn (your beard is brown compared to how mine usually looks), although my head hair is a single patch of always black hair and the rest a fluctuating range of sandy brown to a dark auburn/brown. I’m never exposed to sunlight as I’ve had skin cancer multiple times (before even reaching 30), and if I have to go out in the sun I completely cover up from head to toe; hats and all. So that’s at least not the only factor contributing to my hair color changing (and the black patch never lightens). 

When I bleached my hair as a kid the brown part turned completely blonde, but the black patch just became that same color of orange someone with naturally African hair gets when they bleach it. Oddly enough the skin below the black patch of hair is as pale as most of my skin, but I have a few patches of dark brown skin across my body that matches the skin tone of my darker cousin and my body hair does grow in black, thicker, and longer in those places like theirs too. As a small child I would get freckles on my pale skin that would come and go, but then never again other than 1 time when I was 18 and got lost on a hike severely burning my arms which after the redness retreated left permanent freckles and a couple concerning (but proved non-cancerous) new moles that were removed.

My mom’s always been light skinned (with dark auburn hair), but not colorless like me. Although I did have a great-grandfather on her side that had the skin like I do as well as reddish white hair (he died about mid-life of skin cancer), and my biodad is white-American of mostly Irish and German descent. My mother has the same weird eyes I do though, so I definitely know where I got those from. She’s the only one though, as the rest of her family have brown eyes. 

My eyes were blue when I was born, but darkened into brown as I got older, then lightened back to blue, then darkened to a green, kept going, and just never really settled. Like my mom my eye color still fluctuates between a pale light blue and brown, although as I get older (as it’s been with her) it sits more often on the cooler end of the spectrum. The changes occur over weeks or longer as melanin builds up or breaks down, so it’s not something that makes me really stand out in public or anything. It’s also not dependent on the hair color fluctuations; the 2 seem to change at different random rates.

They can even be slightly different colors, where one is more blue and the other more green (that can make me stick out; but rarely happens), or one a lighter brown, but never far off from one another. Sometimes they even look a gold/amber/yellow color; depending on how the pattern changes. Unlike the color the patten changes fast enough that one could see it, rarely changing significantly at a rate faster than over a day though. 

It’s a bit of a subtle feature as far as looks go though. So one would have to like stare an inch away from my eye for several minutes to an hour to be convinced (as some friends/acquaintances have done), unless they were particularly observant. I almost never mention it in person, but I have had a few friends that were known for having an eye for details where I’d hang out with them every couple weeks and that was enough for them to notice the change in color and pattern; then they tell other people and those people want to see.

My hair is kind of auburn/moggy tortoiseshell, and I've had some weird experiences with pain that, in hindsight, this video explained. I remember having a very bad bout of cellulitis (as in, had to be rushed to hospital to be put on IV antibiotics for a week bad,) and when I was in the ambulance, the paramedic asked me if I wanted medication for the pain. I was a bit confused by this, because, as far as I could tell, I wasn't in enough pain to need medication, so I said no, I'm fine thanks. "It's okay to need painkillers, you know - don't think you need to be brave and tough it out," he said. I assured him I wasn't doing that. He pointed to the heart monitor I was attached to, and explained that he could tell I was in pain because my pulse and heart rate were racing, and that was typical of someone with my condition who was in a lot of pain. Well then I was REALLY confused, and found myself scrutinising my senses and thinking "AM I in pain then? I don't feel like I'm in painkiller-worthy pain, but maybe I'm just being unobservant..." (I also had a temperature of 105, so it was possible my brain wasn't firing on all cylinders.) In the end I decided to take his word for it and agreed to have the medication.

There are times I wish I could pass my pain to non-redheads like in Powder to see if my regular pains are crippling to them. As a blue-eyed redhead with an L6 vertebrae, I make up less than a fraction of a percent of the population, a.k.a. a freak of nature ;-P. The only significant lack of feeling pain experience I've had was when I sliced the inside of my right foot open 3 inches, I had apparently cut it open on the bracket for a dresser mirror that was on the floor, I only noticed it when my foot felt wet from blood. Next to that, I was jumped by people trying to steal stuff I had in a bag I had, they pummeled my neck, back, and shoulders which didn't really seem to hurt like it should've in the slightest. It wasn't until one of them smashed an empty 40oz bottle over my head that disoriented me a little and caused them to back off slightly, giving me the chance to get away. I even called my friends that I'd left earlier that day and joked about it as soon as I got home. On the other side of the scale, a little cut in my cuticle can absolutely drive me insane. I can attest to the anesthetic aspect, even as a kid, I've always needed a lot more to dull my senses. I don't usually bother with pain meds since it takes so much to even have the slightest, if any, effect. I either use ice/heat/stretching, just deal with it, or take a lot of naproxen sodium to try to get relief.

Yeah, years ago I fell into a traffic barrier and didn't realize I had broken my arm until the next day when it started swelling up and it lost all function (thankfully, it was the left one, not the mousing one).
